clinical_study.brief_title: Focusing on Body Functionality After Bariatric Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Does Focusing on Body Functionality Improve Body Image Among Women Who Have Undergone Bariatric Surgery?

brief_summary.textblock: This study investigated whether focusing on one's body functionality (i.e., everything the body can do, rather than how it looks) would lead to improvements in body image, self-esteem, and self-kindness among women who have undergone bariatric surgery.

study_design_info.masking_description: Participants are randomised to group by the online research system. The investigator does not know what group participants have been assigned to. Participants are aware whether they have been assigned to the intervention or comparison (waitlist) group.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in appearance satisfaction over time (pretest, posttest, follow-ups)
primary_outcome.description: Appearance satisfaction was assessed using the Body Areas Satisfaction Subscale (BASS) of the Multidimensional Body-Self Relations Questionnaire (MBSRQ). Scores range from 1-5, with higher scores demonstrating higher appearance satisfaction.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in functionality satisfaction over time (pretest, posttest, follow-ups)
primary_outcome.description: Functionality satisfaction was assessed using the Physical Condition Subscale (PCS) of the Body Esteem Scale (BES). Scores range from 1-5, with higher scores demonstrating higher functionality satisfaction.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in body appreciation over time (pretest, posttest, follow-ups)
primary_outcome.description: Body appreciation was assessed using the Body Appreciation Scale-2 (BAS-2). Scores range from 1-5, with higher scores demonstrating higher body appreciation.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in body responsiveness over time (pretest, posttest, follow-ups)
primary_outcome.description: Body responsiveness was assessed using the Body Responsiveness Questionnaire (BRQ). Scores range from 1-7, with higher scores demonstrating higher body responsiveness.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in self-objectification over time (pretest, posttest, follow-ups)
primary_outcome.description: Self-objectification was assessed using the Self-Objectification Questionnaire (SOQ). Scores range from -25 to 25, with lower scores demonstrating higher levels of self-objectification.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in self-esteem over time (pretest, posttest, follow-ups)
secondary_outcome.description: Self-esteem was assessed using the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE). Scores range from 10-40, with higher scores reflecting higher levels of self-esteem.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in self-kindness over time (pretest, posttest, follow-ups)
secondary_outcome.description: Self-kindness was assessed using the Self-Kindness Subscale (SKS) of the Self-Compassion Scale (SCS). Scores range from 1-7, with higher scores reflecting higher levels of self-kindness.

arm_group.description: Participants in the intervention group completed the Expand Your Horizon programme (Alleva et al., 2015).
Participants in the comparison group did not complete any intervention (i.e., this was a waitlist comparison group).

intervention.description: Expand Your Horizon is an online programme, comprising three 15min writing exercises delivered over the course of 1 week. In each writing exercise, participants are asked to describe the functions of their body, and why those are personally meaningful to them.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Identifying as female, being between 18 and 65 years old, having undergone bariatric surgery 5-7 months prior to the study, and qualifying for standard aftercare at the Nederlandse Obesitas Kliniek (NOK; Dutch Obesity Clinic).
Exclusion Criteria:
- N/A

reference.citation: Alleva JM, Martijn C, Van Breukelen GJ, Jansen A, Karos K. Expand Your Horizon: A programme that improves body image and reduces self-objectification by training women to focus on body functionality. Body Image. 2015 Sep;15:81-9. doi: 10.1016/j.bodyim.2015.07.001. Epub 2015 Aug 14.

patient_data.ipd_description: Anonymised quantitative data (SPSS file) will be uploaded to DataVerse, and will be accessible upon request from the Principal Investigator. Study protocol and informed consent sheet will be available via ClinicalTrials.gov registration.
patient_data.ipd_time_frame: The data will become available as soon as the manuscript is published, with no deadline. The study protocol and informed consent sheet will be available immediately, with no deadline.
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Data will be available to other researchers for non-commercial purposes. Qualitative data (derived from participants' responses to the writing exercises) will not be shared, given the sensitive nature of the data, and given that participants did not provide consent for their writing exercises to be shared outside of the research team. Study protocol and informed consent sheet will be available for non-commercial purposes via ClinicalTrials.gov registration.
